RelatedSentence: Iceland names its commercial aircraft after its volcanoes - ironic , given that ash blown into the atmosphere by the 2010 eruption of the country 's Eyjafjallajökull volcano resulted in much of Europe 's airspace being closed for days , with 100,000 flights cancelled and ten million passengers stranded .

Iceland names its commercial aircraft after its volcanoes - ironic , given that ash blown into the atmosphere by the 2010 eruption of the country 's Eyjafjallajökull volcano resulted in much of Europe 's airspace being closed for days , with 100,000 flights cancelled and ten million passengers stranded .
The locals tend to ignore the odd rumble and giant cloud of fire and ash , which would have those of us living in less explosive regions disappearing under our beds .

RelatedSentence: The Laki volcanic eruption in 1783 was a very different matter , one of the most devastating in recent history , an event that has even the phlegmatic Icelanders quaking at the Earth 's explosive power .
Island on Fire , a new book by Alexandra Witze and Jeff Kanipe , details the local and global impact of Laki 's eruption .
Hot ash and cinders burned skin and poisoned pastures .
Hot ash and cinders burned skin and poisoned pastures .
Over the course of eight months , Laki produced one of the largest lava flows in historic times − enough to bury Manhattan 250 metres deep .
Laki first started erupting in June 1783 .
Throughout the summer of that year , it heaved and spewed particles that spread across Europe .
Today , we know far more about volcanic eruptions , but , as Witze and Kanipe point out , we are none the less vulnerable .

A0: the 2010 eruption of the country 's Eyjafjallajokull volcano
RelatedSentence: The 2010 eruption of Eyjafjallajökull was relatively small in volcanic terms , yet it showed that in our just-in-time world , with its highly - integrated transport and trading systems , one major kink in the network can lead to chaos on a global scale .
The smog of the European summer of 1783 gave way to the worst winter in decades as Laki 's aerosols chilled the continent .
The smog of the European summer of 1783 gave way to the worst winter in decades as Laki 's aerosols chilled the continent .
Studies show a large spike in death rates in England over the period .

Witze and Kanipe say that as crops failed and famine spread in France , Laki could well have been an unseen player behind the French revolution of 1789 - in the same way that a prolonged drought in the eastern Mediterranean has , in part , driven events behind the uprising in Syria .

Witze and Kanipe say that as crops failed and famine spread in France , Laki could well have been an unseen player behind the French revolution of 1789 - in the same way that a prolonged drought in the eastern Mediterranean has , in part , driven events behind the uprising in Syria .
Witze and Kanipe estimate that , overall , millions of people around the world could have died as a result of Laki 's belching and heaving .
This , say the authors , is due in part to climate change .
As the country 's ice has melted , the overlying weight of ice on its volcanoes has been reduced , and the loss of ice is creating geological stresses in the crust beneath .
It 's simple cork - and - champagne physics , say Witze and Kanipe .
This is n't an article about climate change increasing volcanic eruptions , as far as I can see , this is about volcanic eruptions and pollutions having socioeconomic consequences .
